On Tue, 2005-09-13 at 08:35 +0200, Bjarne Andersen wrote:

> With the ARFrontier every single URI is held constantly in the queue - 
> with self adapting revisiting time - this means that every single URI 
> holds its own information about when to be refetched. With every feth 
> this "waittime" is lowered if the page had actually changed and raised 
> if the page was the same as last time.
> 
> The ARFrontier does not use HEAD requests at all (hope I recall right on 
> this one).
> 
> With your approach you will have to revisit all pages (with HEAD 
> requests) on a regularly basis - with some pages altered with only few 
> minutes between it will be a large overhead - even though you use only 
> HEAD requests (at least for some sites)
> 
> The check for updating is done with a simple md5 at the moment (it means 
> fetching the actual content every time) - this could be altered to  use 
> http-headers (even though they are not always reliable).
> 

Ahh.. Thanks for explaining that. Makes perfect sense. :) 

I noticed that the ARFrontier is still experimental.. In your opinion,
would it be stable enough for production use? Is that what the Internet
Archive uses?

> The ARFrontier might work in your setup - but I don't see why you would 
> run with both your filter and the ARFrontier ?

Ah yes of course.. I would either use one or the other.

Thanks very much for your help. :)

Regards,
Dennis
